Award.AwardTitle: Cerebellar Specializations for Non-Vocal Avian C ourtship Displays
Award.AbstractNarration: To attract females, male birds perform spectacular songs and dances. Studies of song have influenced our thinking about how brains adapt for vocal learning, and, because songs are a part of courtship, have taught us how gonadal hormones regulate vocal signals. However, the dances that elevate bird songs to elegant courtship displays have been neglected by scientists. Given the exciting implications of hormone regulated neuroplasticity in brain-motor systems involved in dance, it is surprising that more research has not been done in this this area. This project will use a comparative approach employing neuroanatomical and molecular techniques to determine if the complexity of neural architecture and hormone sensitivity in motor brain regions, like the cerebellum, are positively associated with dance complexity in birds. Thirteen species of the manakin family (Pipridae) that have a range of dance complexities will be compared. Males of a species with one of the most complex displays announce the breeding season with firecracker-like snaps of the wings that punctuate flips performed so fast that high-speed cameras are required to see them. Males of a species with the simplest displays perform a vocal display but have no dance. Imagine how the brains of the former and latter species must differ. The major impact of this study will be to reveal capabilities of the cerebellum and other motor regions to flexibly adapt to demands for motor complexity and to be responsive to hormones in a way not thought possible of motor brain regions. This project will train several graduate and undergraduate students and offers learning opportunities in Central and South America while involving locals in fieldwork. The project will provide tissue samples to museums, create a bank of virtual brain sections, and share DNA sequences for hormone receptors via NCBI websites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Residing in the American tropics is a family of about 60 species of small birds known as “manakins." Males of many manakin species have a reputation for performing acrobatic courtship displays to attract females, but the complexity of displays varies across species (Fig 1). Decades of research with songbirds revealed song-learning brain networks that informed study of speech-learning and language evolution in humans, and has delineated how sex-hormones mediate brain growth and repair in vertebrates including humans. Studying manakins, which attract mates with dance rather than song, we discovered adaptations underlying the evolution of extreme athleticism, apparently driven by female preference for rapid, complex displays. Using high-speed cameras we found that even the humblest of the 13 species we studied executes a back flip faster than humans can see (Fig 1a). Cataloging display motor elements, cooperation (Fig 1b) and substrate preparation (i.e., Fig 1c, arena), we compiled a complexity score and investigated brain and body traits predicted to be positively associated with complexity among species. We found that whole brain size and the size of brain regions involved in sense-motor integration and sequence learning are largest in species with the most complex displays. Regions regulating motivation and relaying visual inputs are unrelated to complexity. Within the sequence learning region of the brain, we found that the number, but not the size of output cells, which direct movement, are associated with greater complexity. Courtship displays are mating behaviors regulated by sex steroids.  Thus, it is not surprising that we found that testosterone increases gene expression in forelimb muscles used by wing-snapping manakins to a greater degree than in non-manakins.  Examining 4 manakin species, we found that display complexity and, in particular, the number of wing-elements, is related to higher androgen, but not estrogen, receptor levels in wing muscles but not spinal cord.  Similarly, fast-ascent displays and wing-snapping displays are coupled with partial solidification of two different wing bones; illustrating that bone density is specialized for specific intense actions. Furthermore, the shape of wing bones is modified in a manner that assists with wing-snapping but could reduce flight efficiency. Lastly, we found a counter-intuitive relationship between body mass and display complexity with heavier, rather than lighter birds, having the most complex displays: a relationship that could be related to bone density and muscle growth.  Lastly, we found a counter-intuitive relationship between body mass and display complexity with heavier, rather than lighter birds, having the most complex displays: a relationship that could be related to bone density and muscle growth. Interestingly, for a relatively large manakin species, body mass does not predict complexity well.  In reviewing high-speed video, we confirmed our complexity score, but found that the larger species produces a “moon walk” differently than its smaller sister species (Fig 2). Compared to the smaller species, we found that the larger species displays on smaller branches higher in the canopy in a more upright position, and that they slide their feet rather than hopping like the smaller species. Presumably, this reduces branch movements to improve balance and suggests that the substrate/weight relationships can influence gait and begs the question of how small changes in motor control develop between these closely related species and the manakin family in general.

Studying manakins, we provide the first evidence that sexual selection for motor complexity is paired with increasing brain size accompanied by modular evolution of motor related areas;  body mass increases with behavioral complexity; and body size/substrate relationships can alter gait and posture. We support prior reports that androgens regulate muscle physiology and that bone morphology adapts to forceful actions. In sum, studying avian courtship reveals an array of evolutionary adaptations for acrobatics in birds and highlights biological traits germane to the physiology and evolution of athleticism in humans and other vertebrates.

In the course this research, we trained and were assisted by: a post-doc, 4 graduate students, and 20 undergraduates, including 2 scientific illustrators, and 4 University of Guyana students. Educational outreach was performed in 4 communities in Guyana, Suriname, and Panama.  Assistants included 11 Amerindians and a recording specialist. We had collaborators at 8 universities, the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute, and the Cornell Lab of Ornithology.  Seven publications and numerous international presentations disseminated our work. Samples and data are shared with researchers and published data from our lab is publiclyy available. Audio and video files will be released by Macaulay Library. Our findings are shared with media outlets, other universities, and community organizations and as part of a manakin Research Collaborative Network. We are proud to make the world aware of the wonder and discoveries afforded by these amazing little manakin gymnasts, which are, ironically, nothing like mannequins.
